Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Neurobiological Basis of Decision Making in Online Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Considerable research in the field has been focused on developing new technologies to enhance privacy; encryption of personal data is often presented as a potential solution. Many of the technologies resulting from this research are not being effectively utilized because of issues rooted in human judgment under risk and uncertainty. The majority of existing models and products related to human judgement are based on a limited number of documented incidents and on questionable assumptions about user intent and behavior. To better develop and apply privacy technologies requires better methods of understanding and measuring human perceptions of privacy.

In this project we are investigating the underlying neurobiological manifestations of privacy, and seeing to understand -- and measure -- variations of uncertainty in online privacy decisions. The outcomes of this proposed project will contribute to answering fundamental questions about human behavior in online environments?e.g., under what circumstances do systems in the mind cooperate or compete in privacy decisions? When there is competition, how and where is it adjudicated? Do higher-level deliberative processes rely similarly on multiple mechanisms, or a single, unitary set of mechanisms? We anticipate these results being used to further refine and develop useful privacy policies and technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most research being carried out today in information privacy focuses on developing new technologies to enhance privacy; encryption of customer data is often presented as a potential solution. At the same time, many of these technologies are not being effectively utilized because of the problems that are endemic to “human” judgment under risk and uncertainty. The vast majority of the existing models and products--validated by paper-and-pencil/web-based surveys/interviews--are mainly based on a limited number of documented incidents and on questionable assumptions about user intent and behavior. For example, they ignore that 1) Online users may not act as rational agents in their privacy decisions, and 2) Privacy is not an object in a unitary process; it involves interaction among multiple subsystems in the mind.

This research has made several contributions into understanding privacy behaviors, and human information processing. First, using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) tools, we neurobiologically investigated human reactions to privacy risks, and opened up the potential leveraging of knowledge of the biological brain to better understand privacy decision making. Our results indicate that privacy decisions are more affective-cognitive, that purely cognitive, as assumed in the existing computational models of privacy decision making. Our results also indicate that in describing privacy decisions, behavioral economics theories are more appropriate than classic decision theories, which assume humans always choose the option with the maximum utility.

Second, collecting data from hundreds of online users about various electronic activities, we found a significant inverse relationship between their assessed risks and benefits (recognizing that the particular technology matters where some technologies are inherently perceived as more risky than others). This develops an enhanced understanding of why online users indicate concern about security and privacy, but when given the opportunity act contrary to their stated intention.

Third, studying the decisions of tens of thousands of online users, this research shed light on understanding choice behavior. Our results violate the assumption that options are evaluated independently, such that the utility of any one option does not depend on other available options. Irrelevant alternatives do indeed influence choice probabilities; introducing an alternative can hurt similar alternatives more than dissimilar ones.

The outcomes of this project have advanced computer and information science and engineering, experimental economics, and social science by adding new brain imaging and emotion-recording technologies for extending and deepening investigations of online decisions. In this project, for the first time, we used fMRI to investigative online privacy decisions. This has been the first step in forming a new discipline; neuroprivacy, that uses neuroscience to inform privacy research, similar to neuroeconomics that informs economics. Additionally, our results could show how computer science, behavioral economics, and decision science can work together to make more “realistic” predictions about human behavior.

The outcomes of this project have established a bridge among computer and information science and engineering, cognitive psychology, economics, and neuroscience to better understand privacy issues as they are perceived by online users. Additionally, by providing a neurobiological basis to compare the results of various privacy training methods, this project has made a unique contribution into teaching, training, and learning about online privacy.
